Stateless refers to shared state, meaning state that is "carried over"
impl=
icitly between requests.

If the client posts a query, and the server respo=
nds with a link to a URL
identifying the specific result of that query as a=
 resource that's normal
server persisted state..

But if the client posts t=
o a /query endpoint and then makes a get to a
generic /result endpoint then=
 the state (or context) is implicitly carried
over and therefore there is n=
o visibility in the second request. I.e there
is shared state and the const=
raint is violated.

Cheers,
M

<p dir=3D"ltr">Stateless refers to shared state, meaning state that is &quo=
t;carried over" implicitly between requests.</p>
<p dir=3D"ltr">If the=
 client posts a query, and the server responds with a link to a URL identif=
ying the specific result of that query as a resource that's normal serv=
er persisted state..</p>
<p dir=3D"ltr">But if the client posts to a /query=
 endpoint and then makes a get to a generic /result endpoint then the state=
 (or context) is implicitly carried over and therefore there is no visibili=
ty in the second request. I.e there is shared state and the constraint is v=
iolated.</p>

<p dir=3D"ltr">Cheers,<br>
M</p>
